summary: Sana Amanat Praises Captain Marvel's Audience Transformation - The Sales Tell a Different Story
title: Sana Amanat Praises Captain Marvel's Audience Transformation - The Sales Tell a Different Story
body:
Sana Amanat Praises Captain Marvel’s Audience Transformation – The Sales Tell a Different Story

Marvel Comics’ Vice President of Content and Character Development recently penned an interview with Brie Larson for InStyle where she praises Marvel Comics’ audience transformation when its comes to their Captain Marvel comics.

Amanat would write:

“As the editor of the Captain Marvel comic, I witnessed firsthand how the audience transformed around Danvers’s re-imagining. A contingency of…

summary: Why people are already against Captain Marvel
title: Why people are already against Captain Marvel
body:
I’ll be the first to admit that… this might turn out to be Marvel’s weakest character introduction. The trailers were standard per every MCU film, but there’s a big difference, and I think that’s this film’s intention.

We understood who these characters were the second their trailers popped up because of the characteristics and charm they displayed. All applause to the actors who had fun portraying them. 

And you know what, Black Panther, while possibly pandering, was a well-made film. I liked it a lot. Probably one of my favorite solo films after Winter Soldier and Iron Man. 

Now we come to Captain Marvel. In the advertisements we’ve seen thus far, two things have been made apparent. “Higher. Further. Faster.” and “With her a hero”. These two lines definitely make the fact that the character is a strong woman apparent. And to add to it, this is coming out on International Women’s Day. 

Huh… I’ll admit, this is pandering. Like seriously obvious pandering to a demographic of whiny babies who want to see characters other than men get to steal the spotlight. 

Well, I don’t want Captain Marvel to kill Thanos in Endgame. That should either go to Tony, Thor, or my favorite pick, Nebula, who is a woman with a backstory with Thanos as his stepdaughter.

There’s also the issue of this film focusing too much on activism and having “boring” trailers. Trailers are only meant to show so much. Honestly, I think the film will… impress audiences. Marvel has a way of bringing out the best of even the most unknown and disliked characters. 

They did something with the Guardians, didn’t they? 

But now for Carol Danvers’ character or lack thereof. We don’t get a general idea of what her character is from the films and I think that’s the point. She doesn’t know who she is either. We learn that she has memories of her past, but she doesn’t remember it. If she doesn’t know who she’s supposed to be, we don’t either.

Whether or not that’s the film’s strength or weakness, we won’t know. First screening reactions have said that it’s good, so I’ll take my chances. I’m seeing it regardless of the people saying what they want. It’s still a Marvel movie in a bigger universe.

I’ll be the first to admit that… this might turn out to be Marvel’s weakest character introduction. The trailers were standard per every MCU film, but there’s a big difference, and I think that’s this film’s intention.

We understood who these characters were the second their trailers popped up because of the characteristics and charm they displayed. All applause to the actors who had fun portraying them. 

And you know what, Black Panther, while possibly pandering, was a well-made film. I liked it a lot. Probably one of my favorite solo films after Winter Soldier and Iron Man. 

Now we come to Captain Marvel. In the advertisements we’ve seen thus far, two things have been made apparent. “Higher. Further. Faster.” and “With her a hero”. These two lines definitely make the fact that the character is a strong woman apparent. And to add to it, this is coming out on International Women’s Day. 

Huh… I’ll admit, this is pandering. Like seriously obvious pandering to a demographic of whiny babies who want to see characters other than men get to steal the spotlight. 

Well, I don’t want Captain Marvel to kill Thanos in Endgame. That should either go to Tony, Thor, or my favorite pick, Nebula, who is a woman with a backstory with Thanos as his stepdaughter.

There’s also the issue of this film focusing too much on activism and having “boring” trailers. Trailers are only meant to show so much. Honestly, I think the film will… impress audiences. Marvel has a way of bringing out the best of even the most unknown and disliked characters. 

They did something with the Guardians, didn’t they? 

But now for Carol Danvers’ character or lack thereof. We don’t get a general idea of what her character is from the films and I think that’s the point. She doesn’t know who she is either. We learn that she has memories of her past, but she doesn’t remember it. If she doesn’t know who she’s supposed to be, we don’t either.

Whether or not that’s the film’s strength or weakness, we won’t know. First screening reactions have said that it’s good, so I’ll take my chances. I’m seeing it regardless of the people saying what they want. It’s still a Marvel movie in a bigger universe.

summary: Boy's Captain Marvel tank top, spotted at Target.  Call me a cynic, but I was worried about how much (if any) Captain Marvel...
